case_vignette:
A 51-year-old white man presents to the clinic with a 2-year history of a painful, recurrent rash on his fingers. He initially noticed redness, irritation, and pustules around his nails that he thought were caused by an infection. However, the rash progressed to affect the nail bed, eventually destroying his nails. On examination, well-demarcated, scaly plaques with associated pustules and nail atrophy are present on the right second and third distal digits. He is otherwise healthy. The patient has a history of eczema and asthma, but these conditions have been well-controlled with medication. The patient is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. He has a family history of psoriasis, but his mother has a history of psoriasis, not his father. The patient is concerned about the appearance of his nails and the potential impact on his work as a software engineer.

A 29-year-old woman with a history of acne presents to the clinic with 3 discrete, atrophic, blue-tinged plaques on her face. The plaques were located on her forehead and cheeks bilaterally. The patient states the lesions had been present for several months and had slowly worsened until they stabilized at their current appearance. The patient reported that the lesions occurred after she went to a physician for “acne treatment.” The patient has no other medical conditions or relevant social history. The patient is a nonsmoker and does not use any medications. The patient’s mother has a history of skin cancer. The patient’s family history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient’s physical examination is notable for the presence of the 3 discrete, atrophic, blue-tinged plaques on her face. The patient’s skin is otherwise normal. The patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. The patient’s laboratory results are unremarkable. The patient’s diagnosis is likely a case of post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) secondary to acne treatment. The patient is advised to use sunscreen and to avoid further sun exposure to prevent worsening of the PIH. The patient is also advised to use a topical corticosteroid to reduce the appearance of the PIH. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 6 weeks to assess the effectiveness of the treatment.

Examination reveals a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule on the right breast. B) Vascular dementia
C) Short-term memory loss
D)  Normal pressure hydrocephalus
E)  Frontotemporal dementia
F)  Lewy body dementia
G)  Mixed dementia
H)  Other
Answer: A) Alzheimer's disease

The patient's symptoms, such as short- and long-term memory deficits, difficulty with word retrieval, and impaired clock drawing, are consistent with Alzheimer's disease. The patient's age and the gradual progression of her symptoms also support this diagnosis. The patient's hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia may contribute to her vascular risk factors, but they do not change the primary diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease.

C) D) Squamous cell carcinoma
D) E) Basal cell carcinoma
Answer: A) Actinic keratosis
Explanation: Actinic keratosis is a common condition that results from chronic sun exposure. It is characterized by rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas, such as the scalp. The lesions are often asymptomatic, but they can be itchy or painful. Actinic keratosis is a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma, and it is often treated with topical medications or cryotherapy. The patient's history of sun exposure as a winemaker makes this diagnosis more likely. The photograph shows a rough, scaly patch on the scalp, which is consistent with actinic keratosis. A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Thoracic outlet syndrome
B) Cervical radiculopathy
C) D) Rotator cuff injury
D) Thoracic outlet syndrome
E) Other (please specify)
Answer: A) Thoracic outlet syndrome
The correct answer is A) Thoracic outlet syndrome. The patient's symptoms, including pain and paresthesias in the left arm and hand, are consistent with thoracic outlet syndrome, which is a condition in which the nerves and/or blood vessels in the thoracic outlet (the space between the neck and shoulder) are compressed. The patient's history of helping a friend set up a canopy tent, which involves repetitive overhead movements, is a common precipitating factor for thoracic outlet syndrome. The physical examination findings, including the patient's symptoms when extending and rotating her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, are also consistent with thoracic outlet syndrome.

A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of slurred speech and left facial droop for the past 30 minutes. During this period, she has also had numbness on the left side of her face. She has never had such an episode before. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her father died of lung cancer 1 week ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 30.5 kg/m2. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left side of the face. Her speech is clear. Examination shows full muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. A finger-nose test and her gait are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a right-sided carotid bruit. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. On the way back from the CT scan, her presenting symptoms resolve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
B) Migraine
C) Dizziness
D) E) None of the above
Answer: A) Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
The correct answer is A) Transient ischemic attack (TIA). The patient's symptoms of slurred speech and left facial droop, which resolved on the way back from the CT scan, are classic for a transient ischemic attack (TIA). A TIA is a temporary interruption of blood flow to the brain, often caused by a blood clot or other blockage in a cerebral artery. The patient's risk factors for TIA, including hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking, are also consistent with this diagnosis.

A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of stiffness and pain in multiple joints. She says that the fingers on both of her hands have become increasingly stiff and difficult to move over the past 8 months. She also complains of nails that break easily and look spotty as well as chronic back pain. She had a urinary tract infection a year ago that was treated with antibiotics. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her vitals are within normal limits. A photograph of her right hand is shown. There are multiple, well-demarcated red plaques with silvery-white scales over the shins and back. Serum studies show a negative rheumatoid factor and ANA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Psoriasis
B) C) Lupus
C) D) Rheumatoid Arthritis
D) E) Sjögren's Syndrome
Answer: A) Psoriasis
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of joint stiffness and pain, easy-to-break nails, and chronic back pain are suggestive of psoriasis. The presence of well-demarcated red plaques with silvery-white scales on the shins and back further supports this diagnosis. The negative rheumatoid factor and ANA make rheumatoid arthritis and lupus less likely. Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, which are not mentioned in the patient's symptoms. 
The best answer is A.

A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

A) Seborrheic dermatitis
B) Psoriasis
C) D) Contact dermatitis
D) E) F) Other

Answer: A) Seborrheic dermatitis

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of concerns about his behavior during the past year. His parents report that he often fails to answer when they call him and has regular unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming. At kindergarten, he can follow and participate in group activities, but does not follow his teacher's instructions when these are given to him directly. He is otherwise cheerful and maintains eye contact when spoken to but does not respond when engaged in play. He gets along well with friends and family. He started walking at the age of 11 months and can speak in two-to-three-word phrases. He often mispronounces words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

A) Autism Spectrum Disorder
B) Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
C) Difficulty with social communication
D) Developmental Delay
E) Hearing Loss
F) Other

The correct answer is A) Autism Spectrum Disorder.

A 3-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of progressive difficulty breathing and a dry cough. Five weeks ago, she was diagnosed with diffuse hemangiomas involving the intrathoracic cavity and started treatment with prednisolone. She appears uncomfortable and in moderate respiratory distress. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 50/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 87%. Oral examination shows a white plaque covering the tongue that bleeds when scraped. Chest examination shows subcostal and intercostal retractions. Scattered fine crackles and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an increased serum beta-D-glucan concentration. An x-ray of the chest shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? A) Blood culture B) C) D) E) Urine antigen test for Histoplasma capsulatum
Answer: B) C) D) E)
Explanation: The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with invasive aspergillosis, a fungal infection that is more common in immunocompromised patients. The patient's history of diffuse hemangiomas and treatment with prednisolone suggests that she is immunocompromised. The presence of a white plaque on the tongue that bleeds when scraped is consistent with oral thrush, a common fungal infection in immunocompromised patients. The increased serum beta-D-glucan concentration is a nonspecific marker of fungal infection. The x-ray of the chest shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates, which is consistent with invasive aspergillosis. The urine antigen test for Histoplasma capsulatum is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. Blood culture (A) is not the most likely to confirm the diagnosis because invasive aspergillosis is not typically diagnosed by blood culture. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of 2 episodes of screaming in the night over the past week. The parents report that their son woke up suddenly screaming, crying, and aggressively kicking his legs around both times. The episodes lasted several minutes and were accompanied by sweating and fast breathing. The parents state that they were unable to stop the episodes and that their son simply went back to sleep when the episodes were over. The patient cannot recall any details of these incidents. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Sleepwalking
B)  Narcolepsy
C)  Sleep apnea
D)  Night terrors
E)  Sleep paralysis
Answer: D)  Night terrors
Explanation: Night terrors are episodes of intense fear or anxiety that occur during deep sleep. They are more common in children than in adults. The episodes are usually brief, lasting from a few minutes to 30 minutes, and the patient is not able to recall any details of the episode. The patient is usually not awakened by the episode and will simply go back to sleep. Sleepwalking, or somnambulism, is a disorder that occurs during the lighter stages of sleep. The patient is usually able to recall details of the episode and is often confused and disoriented. Narcolepsy is a disorder that is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden attacks of sleep. Sleep apnea is a disorder that is characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep. Sleep paralysis is a disorder that is characterized by temporary paralysis of the muscles during sleep. 
The best answer is D. (Skill 1a)  The question requires the test-taker to identify the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described. The correct answer is night terrors, which are episodes of intense fear or anxiety that occur during deep sleep. The other options are incorrect because they do not match the symptoms described. Sleepwalking occurs during the lighter stages of sleep, narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, sleep apnea is characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep, and sleep paralysis is characterized by temporary paralysis of the muscles during sleep.

A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of painless swelling in his left foot for 4 months. The swelling was initially accompanied by redness, which has since resolved. He has not had fever or chills. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has had 3 sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. His mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include clopidogrel, aspirin, metoprolol, losartan, atorvastatin, and insulin. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiovascular examination shows no abnormalities. Examination of the feet shows swelling of the left ankle with collapse of the midfoot arch and prominent malleoli. There is no redness or warmth. There is a small, dry ulcer on the left plantar surface of the 2nd metatarsal. Monofilament testing shows decreased sensation along both feet up to the shins bilaterally. His gait is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Peripheral artery disease
B) Diabetic neuropathy
C) D) Peripheral neuropathy
D) Diabetic foot ulcer
E) Peripheral artery disease with neuropathy
Answer: B) Diabetic neuropathy
The correct answer is B) Diabetic neuropathy. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for diabetic neuropathy. The patient also has decreased sensation along both feet up to the shins bilaterally, which is consistent with diabetic neuropathy. The patient's history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and the presence of decreased sensation make diabetic neuropathy the most likely diagnosis.

A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and was being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and her arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness. She works as an event manager and has had more stress than usual due to a recent concert tour. She appears well. Her temperature is 37°C (98.4°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg. Her cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Vasovagal syncope
B) C) Torsades de Pointes
C) D) Tachyarrhythmia
D) E) Torsades de Pointes
E) F) Tachyarrhythmia
Answer: A) Vasovagal syncope
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of loss of consciousness, diaphoresis, pallor, and a jerky, brief movement of her arms and legs are classic for vasovagal syncope. The fact that she was being tattooed, a painful procedure, and had been experiencing stress due to a recent concert tour, are also risk factors for vasovagal syncope. The ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block, which is a benign finding. Torsades de pointes and tachyarrhythmia are not supported by the patient's symptoms or ECG findings. (Note: The patient's boyfriend is now a girlfriend.) 
The best answer is A.  (Note: The patient's boyfriend is now a girlfriend.) A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided facial weakness that he noticed after waking up. One month ago, he also experienced right-sided neck pain and headache that began after returning from a hunting trip to New Hampshire the week before. He took ibuprofen to relieve symptoms, which subsided a week later. He has a 5-year history of hypertension controlled with drug therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks two beers daily. His vital signs are within the normal range. Physical examination shows right-sided drooping of the upper and lower half of the face. The patient has difficulties smiling and he is unable to close his right eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? 
A) Order a CT scan of the head
B) Order an MRI of the head
C) D) Order a lumbar puncture
D) Order an EMG
E) Order a blood test for Lyme disease
Answer: B) Order an MRI of the head
The best answer is B. The patient's symptoms of right-sided facial weakness, neck pain, and headache, especially after a recent trip to New Hampshire, raise the suspicion of Lyme disease. Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness that can cause facial weakness, neck pain, and headache. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is to order an MRI of the head to rule out other causes of facial weakness, such as a stroke or a tumor. An MRI is more sensitive than a CT scan for detecting soft tissue abnormalities, such as those caused by Lyme disease. An EMG is used to diagnose muscle disorders, such as myasthenia gravis, and is not indicated in this case. A lumbar puncture is used to diagnose meningitis and is not indicated in this case. A blood test for Lyme disease is a good next step, but it should be done after an MRI of the head to rule out other causes of symptoms.

D)  Herpes simplex encephalitis
E)  Herpes zoster encephalitis

The text describes a 23-year-old woman with symptoms of right-sided blurry vision and eye pain, along with a history of low-grade fever, headache, and malaise. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has excessively dry skin. His mother says that he has had dry, scaly skin since he was 6 months old. She says it is worse in winter and better in summer. There is no associated itching, redness, or discharge. Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae (see image). There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Eczema B) Psoriasis C) Seborrheic dermatitis D) Keratosis pilaris
Answer: D) Keratosis pilaris
Explanation: Keratosis pilaris is a benign condition characterized by the appearance of small, rough, sandpapery papules on the skin, especially on the arms and legs. It is caused by the accumulation of keratin in the hair follicles. The condition is more common in children and is often associated with dry skin. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with keratosis pilaris. Eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and scaly skin. Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition characterized by thick, scaly skin. Seborrheic dermatitis is a condition characterized by a red, itchy, and scaly rash, often on the scalp, face, and torso. None of these conditions match the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings.

A 24-year-old male graduate student comes to the physician for a two-month history of repeated thoughts and anxiety that he is going to be harmed by someone on the street. The anxiety worsened after witnessing a pedestrian getting hit by a car two weeks ago. He says, “That was a warning sign.” On his way to school, he now often leaves an hour earlier to take a detour and hide from people that he thinks might hurt him. He is burdened by his coursework and fears that his professors are meaning to fail him. He says his friends are concerned about him but that they do not understand because they were not present at the accident. The patient has no known history of psychiatric illness. On mental status exam, he is alert and oriented, and shows full range of affect. Thought processes and speech are organized. His memory and attention are within normal limits. He denies auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? A) Generalized anxiety disorder B) Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) C) Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) D) Schizophrenia
The correct answer is B) Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The patient's symptoms, such as repeated thoughts of being harmed, anxiety, and avoidance behaviors, are consistent with PTSD. The patient's history of witnessing a pedestrian getting hit by a car and his subsequent anxiety and avoidance behaviors are also consistent with PTSD. The patient's lack of a known history of psychiatric illness and the absence of other symptoms such as hallucinations or disorganized thought processes make the other options less likely.

A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of progressive hair loss over the past 2 months. The parents report that they have noticed increased number of hairless patches on their daughter's head. The patient denies any itching. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient states that she has been feeling tense since her boyfriend broke up with her. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows ill-defined patchy hair loss and hair of different lengths with no scaling or reddening of the scalp. Further examination shows poor hair growth of the eyebrows and eyelashes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Alopecia areata
B) Telogen effluvium
C) D) Trichotillomania
D) Trichorrhexis nodosa
Answer: A) Alopecia areata
Explanation: 
Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disease that causes hair loss. It is characterized by well-defined patches of hair loss. The patient in this case has ill-defined patchy hair loss and hair of different lengths, which is consistent with alopecia areata. Telogen effluvium is a condition that causes excessive hair shedding, but it is not typically associated with patchy hair loss. Trichotillomania is a psychological disorder that causes hair loss due to compulsive pulling of one's hair. Trichorrhexis nodosa is a condition that causes hair breakage due to a defect in the hair shaft. The patient's history of feeling tense since her boyfriend broke up with her may suggest trichotillomania, but the physical examination is more consistent with alopecia areata. 
The best answer is A.

A 77-year-old woman is brought to the physician for gradually increasing confusion and difficulty walking for the past 4 months. Her daughter is concerned because she has been forgetful and seems to be walking more slowly. She has been distracted during her weekly bridge games and her usual television shows. She has also had increasingly frequent episodes of urinary incontinence and now wears an adult diaper daily. She has hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 139/83 mmHg. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. She has a broad-based gait and takes short steps. Sensation is intact and muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? 
A) Normal pressure hydrocephalus
B) Normal pressure hydrocephalus with dementia
C) Dementia
D)  Normal pressure hydrocephalus with dementia and parkinsonism
E)  Normal pressure hydrocephalus with dementia and parkinsonism and depression
Answer: A) Normal pressure hydrocephalus
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia are classic for normal pressure hydrocephalus. The patient's broad-based gait and short steps are indicative of a gait disturbance, and her urinary incontinence is a common symptom of normal pressure hydrocephalus. Her dementia is also consistent with this diagnosis. The patient's normal laboratory studies and lack of other symptoms make the other options less likely. 
The best answer is A.

A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention and twitching of her feet, which her mother noticed a week ago. The patient has also had a low-grade fever for 5 days. She has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. She was born at term and has been healthy since. She is at the 40th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows an irregular palpable mass that crosses the midline of the abdomen. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are erratic movements of the eyes. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Neuroblastoma
B) Wilm's tumor
C) D) Pheochromocytoma
D) Pheochromocytoma
E) None of the above
Answer: A) Neuroblastoma
Explanation: The patient's symptoms and examination findings are consistent with neuroblastoma. The abdominal mass, low-grade fever, and erratic eye movements are all suggestive of this diagnosis. The elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid levels in the urine are also consistent with neuroblastoma, as these are metabolites of catecholamines that are produced by the tumor. The patient's age and sex are also consistent with neuroblastoma, which is more common in young children and has a male predominance. However, the patient in this case is a girl, so the male predominance is not relevant.
The best answer is A.  (Note: The original text had a male pronoun, which was swapped to a female pronoun in the rewritten text.) The patient's history of inconsistent condom use and recent painful sexual intercourse also support this diagnosis. The patient's laboratory studies show an elevated leukocyte count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, indicating an inflammatory process. The patient's regular menstrual cycle and lack of other symptoms make ectopic pregnancy, ovarian torsion, and appendicitis less likely.

case_vignette:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of his “weird” behavior. The parents report that their son tortured their cat to death two weeks ago. Over the past year, he has been accused of stealing a car and setting a fire at his school. He has no history of serious illness. He attends a local high school, and his performance at school is very poor compared to his classmates. He often loses his temper and argues with his teachers. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years. He does not drink alcohol. His mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia controlled with medication. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm, and his thought process is organized. Short- and long-term memory are intact. Attention and concentration are poor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Conduct Disorder
B) Oppositional Defiant Disorder
C) D) Substance Abuse
D) Substance Abuse
E) Schizophrenia
F) Schizotypal Personality Disorder
G) Antisocial Personality Disorder
H) Bipolar Disorder
I) Major Depressive Disorder
J) Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
K) Anxiety Disorder
L) Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
M) Adjustment Disorder
N) Other
The correct answer is A) Conduct Disorder. The key features of this diagnosis are a history of aggression towards people or animals, destruction of property, deceitfulness or theft, and serious violations of rules. The patient's history of torturing a cat, stealing a car, and setting a fire at school are all indicative of conduct disorder. The patient's poor school performance, temper outbursts, and poor attention and concentration are also consistent with this diagnosis. The patient's history of smoking cigarettes is not a key feature of conduct disorder, but it is a common comorbidity. The patient's mother's history of schizophrenia is also not a key feature of conduct disorder, but it may be a contributing factor to the patient's behavior. The patient's poor attention and concentration are also consistent with ADHD, but the key features of conduct disorder are more prominent in this case.

A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute pain in the left eye. He reports having awoken in the morning with a foreign body sensation. He had forgotten to remove his contact lenses before sleeping. Following lens removal, he experienced immediate pain, discomfort, and tearing of the left eye. He reports that the foreign body sensation persists and that rinsing with water has not improved the pain. He has been wearing contact lenses for 4 years and occasionally forgets to remove them at night. He has no history of serious medical illness. On examination, the patient appears distressed with pain and photophobia in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Ocular motility and pupillary response are normal. The corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient? A) Slit-lamp examination B) C) D) E) Corneal foreign body removal
Answer: A) Slit-lamp examination
Explanation: The patient's symptoms are consistent with a corneal foreign body. A slit-lamp examination is the most appropriate diagnostic tool to establish the diagnosis. The patient's symptoms of pain, photophobia, and tearing are consistent with corneal irritation. The patient's history of wearing contact lenses and forgetting to remove them at night is also consistent with a corneal foreign body. The patient's normal visual acuity, ocular motility, and pupillary response suggest that the foreign body is not causing significant damage to the eye. The corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes, which suggests that the foreign body is not causing significant irritation to the cornea. The patient's distress and pain are consistent with a corneal foreign body, and the administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain, which suggests that the foreign body is causing irritation to the cornea. A slit-lamp examination is the most appropriate diagnostic tool to establish the diagnosis of a corneal foreign body. It allows the examiner to visualize the cornea and the foreign body, and to assess the extent of the damage. Corneal foreign body removal (choice E) is a treatment option, not a diagnostic tool. The other options (choices B, C, and D) are not relevant to the diagnosis of a corneal foreign body.

He avoids all family-related events because he has borrowed money from most of his relatives. He is hopeful that his symptoms will improve once he is able to win some of his money back. He previously smoked 8–10 cigarettes daily but quit 1 month ago. He drinks beer on the weekends. On examination, he is uncooperative and dismissive. He is mildly tremulous. B) Pathological gambling
C) D) Other (specify)
D) Substance use disorder
E) Other (specify)
Answer: B) Pathological gambling

The patient's history of smoking and drinking are not relevant to the diagnosis of pathological gambling. The patient's uncooperative and dismissive behavior on examination is also consistent with this diagnosis, as individuals with pathological gambling often deny or minimize their behavior.

A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for 4 months. She describes her stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. During this time she has had a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Physical examination shows pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative and stool microscopy reveals no pathogens and no leukocytes. Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample shows 12 g of fat. The patient is asked to consume 25 g of d-xylose. Five hours later, its concentration is measured in urine at 2 g (N = > 4 g/5 h). The test is repeated after a two-week course of rifaximin, but the urinary concentration of d-xylose remains the same. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
B) Celiac disease
C) D-xylose malabsorption
D)  Bile salt malabsorption
E)  Pancreatic insufficiency
F)  Small intestine bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
G)  Lactose intolerance
H)  Crohn's disease
I)  Ulcerative colitis
J)  Whipple's disease
K)  Cystic fibrosis
L)  Other
The correct answer is D) Bile salt malabsorption. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with bile salt malabsorption, which is a condition in which the small intestine is unable to properly absorb bile salts. This can lead to steatorrhea (fatty stools), weight loss, and other gastrointestinal symptoms. The test of d-xylose absorption is normal, which rules out pancreatic insufficiency and small intestine bacterial overgrowth. The patient's response to rifaximin is also consistent with bile salt malabsorption, as rifaximin is a medication that can help to reduce the amount of bacteria in the small intestine and improve bile salt absorption.

A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. He has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports to hear the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Conductive hearing loss
B) Sensorineural hearing loss
C) Weber test is not specific for hearing loss
D) Weber test is not specific for lateralization
Answer: B) Sensorineural hearing loss
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of progressive hearing loss in both ears, difficulty understanding conversations in crowded places, and no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain are consistent with sensorineural hearing loss. The Weber test results, where the patient hears the tone again when the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear, are also consistent with sensorineural hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss would result in the patient hearing the tone louder in the affected ear. The Weber test is specific for lateralization, and the results in this case are consistent with sensorineural hearing loss. 
The best answer is B.  (Note: The Weber test is a clinical test used to assess lateralization of sound in patients with hearing loss. It is not specific for hearing loss, but rather for lateralization. The correct answer is B) Sensorineural hearing loss.) The patient's family history of psoriasis may also be relevant, as seborrheic dermatitis and psoriasis can share similar symptoms and underlying causes.

A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of abdominal pain, loose, non-bloody stools, and intermittent nausea. He also reports intermittent fever. He has not had vomiting, tenesmus, or rectal pain. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Rectal exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,200/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 44 mm/h. Test of the stool for occult blood and stool studies for infection are negative. A CT scan of the abdomen shows mural thickening and surrounding fat stranding of discrete regions of the terminal ileum and transverse colon. A colonoscopy is performed and biopsy specimens of the affected areas of the colon are taken. Which of the following findings is most specific for this patient's most likely diagnosis? 
A) Ulceration of the mucosa
B) C) Crypt abscesses
C) D) Granulomas
D) E) Non-caseating granulomas
Answer: D) E) Non-caseating granulomas
The correct answer is D) E) Non-caseating granulomas. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Non-caseating granulomas are a hallmark of Crohn's disease and are not typically seen in other types of IBD, such as ulcerative colitis. The other options are not as specific for Crohn's disease: ulceration of the mucosa can be seen in both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, crypt abscesses are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, and granulomas can be seen in other conditions, such as sarcoidosis.

The patient's right leg is shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, which are classic signs of a hip dislocation. The patient's severe pain over the right groin and tenderness to palpation are also consistent with this diagnosis. A femoral neck fracture would likely cause more pain in the thigh, rather than the groin. A femoral shaft fracture would likely cause more pain in the thigh and would not cause the leg to be shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. A hip fracture would likely cause more pain in the groin and would not cause the leg to be shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated.

The correct answer is E) Gouty arthritis. The patient's symptoms of recurrent episodes of joint inflammation, particularly affecting the knee and elbow, are characteristic of gout. The patient's history of a rash is likely related to a urate crystal deposition in the skin, which is a common feature of gout. The physical examination findings of a tender and warm joint, limited range of motion, and cloudy synovial fluid are also consistent with gout. The laboratory findings of a high leukocyte count in the synovial fluid and a predominance of neutrophils are also typical of gout. The diagnosis of gout is confirmed by serologic testing, which shows elevated levels of uric acid and the presence of monosodium urate crystals in the synovial fluid.

B) Osteoblastoma

E) Codman triangle is a characteristic feature of osteosarcoma, but the patient's symptoms are more consistent with osteoblastoma
F) The patient's symptoms are more consistent with osteoblastoma, but Codman triangle is a characteristic feature of osteosarcoma

The correct answer is A) Osteosarcoma.

A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 50 minutes ago. She does not have eye pain. She had several episodes of loss of vision in the past, but her vision improved following treatment with glucocorticoids. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and multiple sclerosis. She underwent a left carotid endarterectomy 3 years ago. She had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metformin, glipizide, and weekly intramuscular beta-interferon injections. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/88 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye and absent in the right eye. The indirect pupillary reflex is brisk in the right eye but absent in the left eye. Intraocular pressure is 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye. A white, 1-mm ring is seen around the circumference of the cornea in both eyes. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows a few soft and hard exudates in the superior and nasal retinal quadrants. The optic disc and macula appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Central retinal artery occlusion
B) Central retinal vein occlusion
C) D) Optic neuritis
D) Central retinal vein occlusion
E) Optic neuritis
Answer: A) Central retinal artery occlusion
The correct answer is A) Central retinal artery occlusion. The patient's symptoms and examination findings are most consistent with central retinal artery occlusion. The patient's sudden loss of vision in one eye, absence of pain, and pale retina with a bright red macula are classic signs of central retinal artery occlusion. The patient's history of multiple sclerosis and previous episodes of loss of vision also support this

A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state on an interstate rest area in Florida. She is unable to recall her name, address, or any other information regarding her person. She denies being the woman on a Connecticut driver's license found in her wallet. A telephone call with the police department of her hometown reveals that she had been reported missing three days ago by her husband. When the husband arrives, he reports that his wife has had a great deal of stress at work lately and before she went missing, was anxious to tell her boss that she will not meet the deadline for her current project. She has had two major depressive episodes within the past 4 years that were treated with citalopram. She drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status exam, she is oriented only to time and place but not to person. Short-term memory is intact; she does not recognize her husband or recall important events of her life. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Dissociative amnesia
B) Dissociative fugue
C) D) Dissociative identity disorder
D) Dissociative amnesia
E) Dissociative fugue
F) Dissociative identity disorder
Answer: B) Dissociative fugue
The correct answer is B) Dissociative fugue. The patient's inability to recall her name, address, or any other information regarding her person, along with her inability to recognize her husband or recall important events of her life, suggests a dissociative fugue. Dissociative fugue is characterized by sudden, unexpected travel away from home or work, with an inability to recall one's past and assume a new identity. The patient's history of stress, anxiety, and major depressive episodes may have contributed to her dissociative fugue. Dissociative amnesia is characterized by an inability to recall specific events or information, but the patient's identity and sense of self remain intact. Dissociative identity disorder is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states, which is not present in this case.

The other options are not as likely given the patient's symptoms and examination findings.

A 71-year-old woman comes to her doctor because she is having trouble staying awake in the evening. Over the past year, she has noticed that she gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. She also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She typically goes to bed around 9 PM and gets out of bed between 2 and 3 AM. She does not have any trouble falling asleep. She takes 30-minute to 1-hour daytime naps approximately 3 times per week. She has no history of severe illness and does not take any medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Narcolepsy
B) C) Hypersomnia
C) D) Insomnia
D) E) Sleep apnea
Answer: B) C) Hypersomnia
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of excessive daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating, combined with her ability to fall asleep quickly and her long sleep duration, are most consistent with hypersomnia. Narcolepsy is characterized by sudden attacks of sleep, which is not present in this patient. Insomnia is characterized by difficulty falling asleep, which is not present in this patient. Sleep apnea is characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep, which is not present in this patient.

A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2 day history of blood-speckled stools and a protruding rectal mass. He has no abdominal pain, altered bowel habits, or fever. His mother has inflammatory bowel disease. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple, small, hyperpigmented maculae on the lips, buccal mucosa, palms, and soles. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Rectal examination shows a 4-cm pedunculated polyp with superficial excoriations on the mucosa. A colonoscopy shows 14 polyps. A biopsy shows hamartomatous mucosal polyps. This patient's diagnosis is most likely associated with which of the following conditions? 
A) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
B) Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
C) D) Other
D) Other
Answer: B) Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
Explanation: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and mucocutaneous melanin deposits. The patient in this question has a history of multiple polyps and mucocutaneous melanin deposits (the hyperpigmented maculae on the lips, buccal mucosa, palms, and soles). The patient's family history of inflammatory bowel disease is not relevant to the diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a different condition characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon. The patient in this question has hamartomatous polyps, not adenomatous polyps. The patient's diagnosis is most likely associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. 
The best answer is B.  (Note: The question and answer choices are written in a way that assumes a male patient. The question and answer choices should be rewritten to be gender-neutral.)  (Skill 1a)

A previously healthy 56-year-old woman comes to the family physician for a 1-month history of sleep disturbance and sadness. The symptoms have been occurring since her husband died in a car accident. Before eventually falling asleep, she stays awake for multiple hours and has crying spells. Several times she has been woken up by the sound of her husband calling her name. She has lost 3 kg (6.6 lb) over the past month. She has 3 children with whom she still keeps regular contact and regularly attends church services with her friends. She expresses feeling a great feeling of loss over the death of her husband. She has no suicidal ideation. She is alert and oriented. Neurological exam shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms? 
A) Adjustment disorder with depressed mood
B) Major depressive disorder
C) Dysthymic disorder
D)  Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood
E)  Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct
Answer: A) Adjustment disorder with depressed mood
The correct answer is A) Adjustment disorder with depressed mood. The patient's symptoms began after the death of her husband, and she is experiencing a normal grief reaction. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is characterized by the development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor, such as the death of a loved one. The symptoms must cause significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning. The patient's symptoms are causing her significant distress, but she is still able to care for her children and attend church services. She also has no suicidal ideation, which is a key feature of major depressive disorder. The patient's symptoms are not severe enough to meet the criteria for major depressive disorder, and she does not have a history of chronic depression, which would be characteristic of dysthymic disorder. Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood and adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct are not supported by the patient's symptoms.

A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a painful skin lesion on her right leg for 1 month. It initially started out as a small red spot but has rapidly increased in size during this period. She remembers an ant bite on her leg prior to the lesion occurring. She was treated for anterior uveitis 8 months ago with corticosteroids. She has Crohn's disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Current medications include insulin, mesalamine, enalapril, and aspirin. She returned from Wisconsin after visiting her son 2 months ago. Her temperature is 37.6°C (98°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 126/88 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting pedal edema of the lower extremities. There is a 4-cm tender ulcerative lesion on the anterior right leg with a central necrotic base and purplish irregular borders. There are dilated tortuous veins in both lower legs. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpated bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Cellulitis
B) Erythema nodosum
C)  Venous insufficiency
D)  Erythema multiforme
E)  Pyoderma gangrenosum
Answer: E) Pyoderma gangrenosum
The correct answer is E) Pyoderma gangrenosum. The patient's history of Crohn's disease and the presence of a tender ulcerative lesion with a central necrotic base and purplish irregular borders are characteristic of pyoderma gangrenosum. The other options are less likely given the patient's presentation and history. Cellulitis typically presents with warmth, redness, and swelling, but not typically with a central necrotic base. Erythema nodosum is characterized by tender, erythematous nodules, usually on the lower extremities, but not typically with a central necrotic base. Venous insufficiency typically presents with dilated tortuous veins and pitting pedal edema, but not typically with a tender ulcerative lesion. Erythema multiforme is characterized by target-like lesions, usually on the extremities, but not typically with a central necrotic base.

Female sexual arousal disorder is characterized by difficulty becoming aroused, which is not present in this patient. 
The best answer is B.  (Note: The original text was written in a way that was not inclusive of all individuals who may experience vaginismus. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2/6 continuous, low-pitched murmur over the left upper sternal border that radiates towards the neck. The murmur disappears when she flexes her neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

A) Aortic stenosis
B) C) Mitral stenosis
C) D) Patent ductus arteriosus
D) E) Tricuspid atresia

Answer: C) Patent ductus arteriosus

Explanation: The murmur described is a continuous murmur that radiates towards the neck. This is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus, which is a congenital heart defect that occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. The murmur is continuous because it is caused by blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary artery through the patent ductus arteriosus. The fact that the murmur disappears when the child flexes her neck is also consistent with this diagnosis, as this maneuver can compress the ductus arteriosus and reduce blood flow through it. 

Note: The other options are not correct because aortic stenosis typically produces a systolic ejection murmur, mitral stenosis typically produces a diastolic murmur, and tricuspid atresia typically produces a systolic ejection murmur.

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on his chest. His mother says that he has no history of dermatological problems. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of otitis media. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/62 mm Hg. Examination shows vesicles and flaccid bullae with thin brown crusts on the chest. Lateral traction of the surrounding skin leads to sloughing. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Erythema multiforme
B) C) Bullous pemphigoid
C) D) Stevens-Johnson syndrome
D) E) Pemphigus vulgaris
Answer: B) C) Bullous pemphigoid
Explanation: Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic autoimmune skin disease that typically presents in the elderly, but it can occur in children. The disease is characterized by the formation of tense bullae on the skin, which can be accompanied by pruritus. The bullae are usually not painful and do not rupture easily. The oral mucosa is typically spared. The diagnosis is confirmed by a biopsy of the affected skin, which shows a subepidermal blister. The other options are incorrect because erythema multiforme is characterized by target lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe form of erythema multiforme that involves the mucous membranes, and pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune skin disease that presents with flaccid bullae on the skin and mucous membranes. 
The best answer is B.

D) Schizoid personality disorder

The patient's symptoms are not better explained by another mental disorder, such as a mood disorder with psychotic features. The patient's symptoms are not better explained by a personality disorder, such as schizoid personality disorder or schizotypal personality disorder. The patient's symptoms are not better explained by a brief psychotic disorder, such as schizoaffective disorder. The patient's symptoms are not better explained by a substance-induced psychotic disorder, such as substance-induced psychosis.

Asthma is not consistent with the patient's history of smoking and spirometry results.
The best answer is B.

A) Osteosarcoma
B) Ewing's sarcoma

E) F) Ewing's sarcoma

The correct answer is B) Ewing's sarcoma. This is a classic description of Ewing's sarcoma. The biopsy findings of small round blue cells also support this diagnosis. Osteosarcoma typically presents with a mix of lytic and sclerotic lesions, and the biopsy findings would show malignant osteoid. Lymphoma can present with a variety of radiographic findings, but the biopsy findings would show lymphoid cells. Osteoblastoma is a benign tumor that typically presents with a well-defined lytic lesion.

A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of swelling in his left arm. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with a deep venous thrombosis in the left calf. He has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss in the last 3 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. His only medication is warfarin. Physical examination shows warm edema of the left forearm with overlying erythema and a tender, palpable cord-like structure along the medial arm. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. D) D-dimer test

The patient's history of smoking and weight loss also increases the risk of pulmonary embolism. The D-dimer test is not specific for pulmonary embolism and can be elevated in many conditions, including cancer, trauma, and infection. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate next step in this case.

This is a classic case of a battered woman syndrome, which is a type of major depressive disorder. The patient's symptoms are not indicative of adjustment disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, or somatization disorder.

A) Alzheimer's disease
B) Normal pressure hydrocephalus
C) gait apraxia
D)  Parkinson's disease
E)  Normal
Answer: B) Normal pressure hydrocephalus
The correct answer is B) Normal pressure hydrocephalus. The patient's symptoms of gait disturbance, urinary urgency, and cognitive decline are classic for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). NPH is a condition in which there is an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain's ventricles, leading to increased pressure and damage to surrounding brain tissue. The symptoms of NPH are often described as the "classic triad" of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence or urgency, and cognitive decline. The patient's slow, broad-based gait and difficulty concentrating on his writing are consistent with NPH. The patient's normal urinalysis and lack of other neurological abnormalities make other diagnoses less likely.

A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of weakness and intermittent burning pain in her neck, shoulders, and arms. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 1 year ago. Examination of the upper extremities shows absent reflexes, muscle weakness, and fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent; vibration and proprioception are preserved. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
B) Multiple sclerosis (MS)
C) D) Myasthenia gravis
D) Guillain-Barré syndrome
E) Polymyositis
Answer: A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
The correct answer is A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The patient's symptoms, including muscle weakness, absent reflexes, and fasciculations, are consistent with ALS. ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. The patient's history of a motor vehicle collision is not relevant to the diagnosis of ALS. The other options are not consistent with the patient's symptoms. Multiple sclerosis (MS) typically presents with sensory symptoms, such as numbness or tingling, and visual disturbances. Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that affects the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness that worsens with activity. Guillain-Barré syndrome is an autoimmune disease that affects the peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis. Polymyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease that leads to muscle weakness and pain.

A 32-year-old man comes to the physician for a 1-month history of fever, chest pain with deep breathing, and a 4-kg (9 lb) weight loss. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). An x-ray of the chest shows a subpleural nodule in the right lower lobe with right hilar lymphadenopathy. Histological examination of a right hilar lymph node biopsy specimen shows several granulomas with acellular cores. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

B) Sarcoidosis
C) D) Other
D) Other
Answer: B) Sarcoidosis
Explanation: The patient's symptoms and the histological findings are consistent with sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterized by the formation of noncaseating granulomas in various organs, including the lungs. The patient's symptoms of fever, chest pain, and weight loss are common in sarcoidosis. The presence of granulomas with acellular cores in the lymph node biopsy specimen is also consistent with sarcoidosis. Tuberculosis is less likely because the granulomas in tuberculosis are typically caseating, and the patient's symptoms and histological findings do not suggest an infectious process.
The best answer is B.

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-week history of generalized fatigue, intermittent fever, and occasional bleeding from his nose. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). He appears pale. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy and multiple petechiae on his trunk. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 63,000/mm3, and platelet count is 30,000/mm3. A bone marrow aspirate predominantly shows immature leukocytes that stain positive for CD10, CD19, and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT), and negative for myeloperoxidase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
B) Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
C)  Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
D)  Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)
E)  Hairy cell leukemia
Answer: A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
The correct answer is A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with ALL, a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. The presence of immature leukocytes that stain positive for CD10, CD19, and TdT, and negative for myeloperoxidase, is characteristic of ALL. The patient's low hemoglobin concentration, high leukocyte count, and low platelet count also support this diagnosis.

His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination shows significant weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. He is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine. He is able to stand on his toes. His gait is unsteady. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain and MR angiography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Guillain-Barré syndrome
B) Myasthenia gravis
C) Muscle weakness due to a medication side effect
D) Muscle weakness due to a vitamin deficiency
E) Other

The correct answer is A) Guillain-Barré syndrome.

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Hypoglycemia due to insulinoma B) Hypoglycemia due to sulfonylurea overdose C) Hypoglycemia due to insulin therapy D) Hypoglycemia due to factitious hypoglycemia E) Hypoglylucemia due to gastroparesis
Answer: E) Hypoglycemia due to gastroparesis
The correct answer is E) Hypoglycemia due to gastroparesis. The boy's symptoms and lab results are consistent with gastroparesis, a condition in which the stomach takes too long to empty its contents. This can lead to delayed gastric emptying, which in turn can cause hypoglycemia. The boy's mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for gastroparesis. The boy's symptoms and lab results do not suggest an insulinoma, sulfonylurea overdose, insulin therapy, or factitious hypoglycemia.

A) Hodgkin lymphoma
B) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
C) D) Other lymphoma
D) Other lymphoma
E) Other lymphoma
Answer: B
Explanation: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The patient's age, weight loss, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy are all consistent with lymphoma. The presence of a fixed supraclavicular lymph node is a poor prognostic sign. The patient's lymph node biopsy shows lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20, which is consistent with a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The patient's age and symptoms are not consistent with a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, which typically presents in younger patients and is associated with a more indolent course.
The best answer is B.

A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of body aches for the past 9 months. She also has stiffness of the shoulders and knees that is worse in the morning and tingling in the upper extremities. Examination shows marked tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee. A complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Rheumatoid arthritis
B) Fibromyalgia
C) D) Osteoarthritis
D) Osteoporosis
E) Other
Answer: B) Fibromyalgia
Explanation: Fibromyalgia is a condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points. The patient's symptoms of body aches, stiffness, and tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee are consistent with fibromyalgia. The absence of systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or elevated inflammatory markers makes rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis less likely. Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density, which is not indicated by the patient's symptoms or examination findings. 
The best answer is B. (Skill 1a)

An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, itchy rash, and generalized joint pain. The rash initially started in the antecubital and popliteal fossae and then spread to her trunk and distal extremities. One week ago, she was diagnosed with acute sinusitis and was started on amoxicillin. She has no history of adverse drug reactions and immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and multiple erythematous, annular plaques of variable sizes over her entire body. One of the lesions in the right popliteal fossa has an area of central clearing and the patient's mother reports that it has been present for over 24 hours. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Erythema multiforme
B) Erythema nodosum
C) DRESS syndrome
D) DRESS syndrome is a drug reaction that is more common in females, but it is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.
Answer: C) DRESS syndrome
The correct answer is C) DRESS syndrome. The patient's symptoms, including the rash, fever, and joint pain, are consistent with DRESS syndrome, which is a drug reaction that can occur after the use of certain medications, including amoxicillin. DRESS syndrome is more common in females, but it is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. The other options are incorrect because erythema multiforme is a different condition that typically presents with target-like lesions, erythema nodosum is a condition that typically presents with painful nodules on the lower extremities, and the statement about DRESS syndrome being more common in females is incorrect.

The presence of hemorrhage in the tumor would make option C or E more likely.

A) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, B) CT scan of the chest, C) D-dimer test, D) CT scan of the leg.
Answer: C) D-dimer test
Explanation: The patient has symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is a common complication in patients with cancer. A CT scan of the leg (D) may be helpful in evaluating for DVT, but it is not the best test.

The correct answer is B) Serology for the presence of antibodies to the parasite Leishmania.

The patient's physical examination shows lymphadenopathy, which is also consistent with visceral leishmaniasis. The diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis is typically confirmed by serology for the presence of antibodies to the parasite Leishmania. PCR for the presence of the parasite Leishmania is not typically used to confirm the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis. PCR for the presence of the parasite Plasmodium falciparum is used to diagnose malaria, which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms and travel history. Serology for the presence of antibodies to the parasite Toxoplasma gondii is used to diagnose toxoplasmosis, which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms and travel history.

The correct answer is B) Serology for the presence of antibodies to the parasite Leishmania.

Physical examination shows drooping of her right upper eyelid that worsens when the patient is asked to gaze at the ceiling for 2 minutes. There is diminished motor strength in the upper extremities. A) Myasthenia gravis
B) Multiple sclerosis
C) Dystonia
D) E) Myotonic dystrophy
Answer: A) Myasthenia gravis
The correct answer is A) Myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue. The symptoms described in the scenario, such as double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and weakness when trying to brush her hair, are consistent with myasthenia gravis. The fact that the symptoms worsen after exercise and improve with rest is also characteristic of the disease. The physical examination findings, including drooping of the eyelid and diminished motor strength in the upper extremities, further support this diagnosis. The other options are not consistent with the symptoms and examination findings described in the scenario. Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating disease that affects the central nervous system, dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, and myotonic dystrophy is a genetic disorder that affects muscle tone and strength.

D) E) Pelvic inflammatory disease
Answer: C) D) Imperforate hymen
Explanation: The patient's symptoms of recurrent lower abdominal pain, absence of menarche, and bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus are suggestive of an imperforate hymen. This condition occurs when the hymen completely covers the vaginal opening, preventing menstrual blood from exiting the body. The bulging, bluish tissue is likely menstrual blood that has accumulated behind the imperforate hymen. The patient's Tanner stage 4 pubic hair and breast development indicate that she is likely in the late stages of puberty, which is consistent with the diagnosis of an imperforate hymen. Ovarian cysts and ovarian torsion are less likely because they would not cause the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen. Pelvic inflammatory disease is also less likely because it would not cause the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen and would likely be accompanied by other symptoms such as fever and abdominal tenderness. 
The best answer is D.

B) Painful shoulder dislocation

Explanation: The child's presentation is classic for a fracture of the right clavicle. The mechanism of injury is a fall onto an outstretched arm, which is a common mechanism for clavicle fractures. The child's refusal to move the arm and the holding of the arm close to the body are also classic signs of a clavicle fracture. The humerus is a long bone in the upper arm, and a fracture of the humerus would likely result in more severe symptoms, such as inability to move the arm at all. A painful shoulder dislocation would also result in more severe symptoms, such as inability to move the arm at all. The child's symptoms are not severe enough to suggest a dislocation.
The best answer is C.

An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence. The symptoms worsen when she has pizza or ice cream and have become more frequent over the past 4 months. Lactose intolerance is suspected. Which of the following findings would most strongly support the diagnosis of lactose intolerance? A) A 1-hour postprandial glucose level of 120 mg/dL. B) 24-hour hydrogen breath test. C) 24-hour stool fat test. D) 24-hour urine nitrogen test.
Answer: B
Explanation: Lactose intolerance is a condition in which the small intestine does not produce enough lactase, the enzyme that breaks down lactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products. The symptoms of lactose intolerance are similar to those of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and include abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence. The symptoms of lactose intolerance worsen when lactose-containing foods are consumed. The 24-hour hydrogen breath test is the most sensitive and specific test for lactose intolerance. This test measures the amount of hydrogen in the breath, which is produced when bacteria in the colon break down undigested lactose. A 1-hour postprandial glucose level of 120 mg/dL is within the normal range and would not support a diagnosis of lactose intolerance. A 24-hour stool fat test is used to diagnose malabsorption of fat, not lactose. A 24-hour urine nitrogen test is used to diagnose kidney disease, not lactose intolerance.
The best answer is B.  (Skill 1a)

A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0 at 11 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of left lower extremity pain and swelling. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination shows a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. The overlying skin is erythematous and indurated. Duplex ultrasound shows vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) DVT
B) C) Superficial thrombophlebitis
C) D) Cellulitis
D) E) Varicose veins
Answer: B) C) Superficial thrombophlebitis
Explanation: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with superficial thrombophlebitis. The presence of a palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg, along with erythema and induration of the overlying skin, are classic signs of this condition. Duplex ultrasound findings of vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema further support this diagnosis. DVT is less likely because it typically presents with more severe symptoms, such as pain and swelling of the entire leg, and is often associated with a positive D-dimer test. Cellulitis is also less likely because it typically presents with more diffuse erythema and swelling, and is often associated with a fever and leukocytosis. A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a cough productive of clear mucoid sputum. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a 2-cm solid nodule in the periphery of the lower left lobe. A bronchial biopsy of the mass shows numerous mucin-filled epithelial cells lining the alveolar basement membrane. The cells have prominent nucleoli, coarse chromatin, and some cells have multiple nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Adenocarcinoma
B) Squamous cell carcinoma
C) D) Small cell carcinoma
D) Adenocarcinoma
E) None of the above
Answer: A) Adenocarcinoma
Explanation: The patient's history of smoking and the presence of mucin-filled epithelial cells lining the alveolar basement membrane are consistent with adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer in smokers and is often associated with mucin production. The presence of prominent nucleoli, coarse chromatin, and multiple nuclei in some cells is also consistent with adenocarcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma is more commonly associated with a history of heavy smoking and is often associated with a central location in the lung. Small cell carcinoma is a highly aggressive type of lung cancer that is often associated with a history of heavy smoking and is often associated with a central location in the lung. 
The best answer is A.
